cards.back:
V = IR

Voltage equals current times resistance.

Alternatively: I = V/R or R = V/I

Electric potential difference — the "push" that drives current through a circuit.

Analogy: Water pressure in pipes.

Unit: Volts (V)

The rate of flow of electric charge.

Analogy: Water flow rate.

Unit: Amperes (A)

Direction: from + to − (conventional)

The opposition to current flow.

Analogy: Narrow pipes restrict water flow.

Unit: Ohms (Ω)

Higher R → less current for same voltage

cards.front: What is conductance? How does it relate to resistance?
cards.back:
G = 1/R

Conductance measures how easily current flows (opposite of resistance).

Unit: Siemens (S)

Higher G → more current for same voltage

cards.front: Write the three power formulas for resistors
cards.back:
P = VI
P = I²R
P = V²/R

Use whichever matches what you're given!

V_out = V_in × (R₂/(R₁+R₂))

Two resistors in series: output taken across R₂.

Voltages divide proportionally to resistances.

cards.front: How do resistances add in series?
cards.back:
R_total = R₁ + R₂ + R₃ + ...

In series: same current flows through all.

Voltages add up.

cards.front: Why is it called a LINEAR resistor?
cards.back:
Because the v-i graph is a STRAIGHT LINE through the origin.

Doubling voltage doubles current (proportional).

Mathematically: V = IR has the form y = mx + 0

cards.front: Why do LEDs always have a resistor in series?
cards.back:
To limit current to ~20mA.

Without it: LED draws huge current → burns out.

R = (V_supply − V_LED) / I_desired

1kΩ = 1000Ω (kilo = ×1000)

50mA = 0.05A (milli = ÷1000)

ALWAYS convert to base units before calculating!

cards.front: What is the relationship between resistance and conductance forms?
cards.back:
V = IR ↔ I = GV

They're DUAL forms (swap V↔I, R↔G).

Same information, different perspectives.

On v-i plane: slope = G
On i-v plane: slope = R
